questions.question_text: Which two queries execute successfully? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: D, E confirmed

comments.content:
NULLIF must have the same data type, not use number and string in the same expression.
COALESCE returns the first non-null value of the expression, but without using numbers and string.

discussion.content: D and E .Confirmed.

D and E are correct.

Selected Answer: DE

A. ORA-00932: inconsistent datatypes: expected - got CHAR
B. ORA-00932: inconsistent datatypes: expected NUMBER got CHAR
C. ORA-00932: inconsistent datatypes: expected NUMBER got CHAR
D. SQL> SELECT COALESCE(100, NULL, 200) FROM DUAL;

COALESCE(100,NULL,200)
----------------------
 100
E. SQL> SELECT NULLIF(100, 100) FROM DUAL;

NULLIF(100,100)
---------------

Tested both

D and E are correct
SQL> SELECT COALESCE(100, NULL, 200) FROM DUAL;

COALESCE(100,NULL,200)
----------------------
 100

SQL> SELECT NULLIF(100, 100) FROM DUAL;

NULLIF(100,100)
---------------

Selected Answer: ACE
A. An index block can contain row data. --> True.
ref: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/A57673_01/DOC/server/doc/SCN73/ch3.htm
B. A data block header is of a fixed length. -->  False.
ref: https://www.dba-oracle.com/t_data_block_format.htm
C. Row data is stored starting at the end of the block. --> True.
ref: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/cncpt/logical-storage-structures.html
D. A table block must always contain row data. --> False.
ref: https://richardfoote.wordpress.com/category/block-dumps/
E. A block header contains a row directory pointing to all rows in the block. --> True.
ref: https://medium.com/geekculture/explain-about-oracle-database-data-block-interview-a-be137c52fe4d

comments.content:
A. An index block can contain row data. --> True, "Row Data" portion : This portion of the block contains table or index data.
B. A data block header is of a fixed length. -->  False, the header of a data block has two areas a "common" area and a "variable" area. In the common area you have a fixed-size block header. ==> But it's different to say, I guess.
C. Row data is stored starting at the end of the block. --> True, "Space Management in Data Blocks" -> As the database fills a data block from the bottom up, the amount of free space between the row data and the block header decreases.
D. A table block must always contain row data. --> False, it also contains info about tab and col: If we look at a partial block dump of one of the table blocks.
E. A block header contains a row directory pointing to all rows in the block. --> True, a block header includes the information about block type information, whether it is a row block or an index block, and the information of tables that have the rows in it, and the row directory, means the addresses of each row in this block.

discussion.content:
Header (Common and Variable)
The header contains general block information, such as the block address and the type of segment; for example, data, index, or rollback. While some block overhead is fixed in size, the total block overhead size is variable. On average, the fixed and variable portions of data block overhead total 84 to 107 bytes.

Selected Answer: BCE
Provided answer are corrects!

comments.content: I'm sorry I was wrong. please remove this full comment with vote.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about data block storage in an Oracle Database? (Choose three.)

choices.B: A data block header is of a fixed length.
choices.A: An index block can contain row data.
choices.E: A block header contains a row directory pointing to all rows in the block.
choices.C: Row data is stored starting at the end of the block.
choices.D: A table block must always contain row data.

choices.E: They can be queried while the database is in the MOUNT state like dynamic performance views.
choices.A: They support DELETES which transparently deletes records in the file system as if they were table rows.
choices.C: They support UPDATES which transparently updates records in the file system as if they were table rows.
choices.B: They can be queried, transformed, and joined with other tables without having to load the data first.
choices.D: The results of a complex join or aggregating function or both can be unloaded to a file for transportation to another database.

If the order is not specified, ASC is the default.

F-FALSE: When a sequence number is generated, the sequence is incremented, independent of the transaction committing or rolling back.
A-TRUE: If two users concurrently increment the same sequence, then the sequence numbers each user acquires may have gaps, because sequence numbers are being generated by the other user

I agree ACD
C-TRUE:when an instance abnormally shuts down (for example, when an
instance failure occurs or a SHUTDOWN ABORT statement is issued), sequence numbers that
have been cached but not used are lost.
The CACHE clause preallocates a set of sequence numbers and keeps them in memory so that
sequence numbers can be accessed faster
D-TRUE: If the sequence is cycle it can generate duplicate values.

Selected Answer: ACD
Agree with A, C and D.

ACD are correct

B is wrong -> "Sequence numbers are generated independently of tables, so the same sequence can be used for one or for multiple tables"

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about sequences in a single instance Oracle database? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Two or more tables cannot have keys generated from the same sequence.
choices.D: A sequence can issue duplicate values.
choices.F: A sequence number that was allocated can be rolled back if a transaction fails.
choices.C: A sequence's unallocated cached values are lost if the instance shuts down.
choices.E: A sequence can only be dropped by a DBA.
